prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim here to detect the CO(1-0) line in these systems and, as argued above, we require ~10 km/s channels. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz (about 2.5 km/s), which we will bin up to 10 km/s in post processing. This configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning for face-on sources, or increase it for edge-on systems to get higher sensitivity. We place one spectral window on 12CO, one on shock tracer CH3OH, one on outflow tracer HC3N, and another on the CN lines (but these do not drive our time estimate). We will use 4x spectral averaging for these windows in order to reduce the data rate, as these lines, if present, are expected to be weak. These windows can also be used to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).

As above, we have assumed that the flux will be only marginally resolved each channel (tracing the spider diagram of the velocity field), as the dust (which is almost always spatially coincident with the molecular gas; Alatalo et al. 2013) visible in the optical image of this object (see Figure 1) appears close to edge-on. We hence estimate the LAS should be ~2" in each channel, and as such we do not expect to resolve out flux. Even if the molecular gas morphology is extremely different to that of the dust, we still expect not to lose flux as the LAS accessible in this array configuration (25.2") extends well beyond the effective radii of these objects.
We will compare this very suppressed early-type galaxy with existing observations of normal gas-rich galaxies (Davis et al. 2014, Leroy et al. 2009), which have been mapped at ~1 kpc resolution. Our angular resolution is chosen so that we have approximately the same physical resolution (which corresponds to 1.5" at the distance of this object), allowing easy comparison and ensuring we will obtain more than 5 beams across the minor merger remnant. This is also the scale where one expects to see large-scale streaming and inflow of gas.

The selected galaxy has a mean line flux of 18.4 mJy/chan, with a line width of 412 km/s based on our IRAM observations (see Figure 1). We assume that this flux will be spread over at most two beam widths in each channel, as the dust (which is almost always spatially coincident with the molecular gas; Alatalo et al. 2013) visible in the optical image of this object (see Figure 1) appears close to edge-on. Thus the flux per beam we need to detect is 9.2 mJy/beam. Requiring a 5 sigma detection of this flux (in order to ensure an accurate estimate of the gas kinematics) yields our requested RMS of 1.8 mJy/beam.
As discussed in our science case, the aim of this proposal is to map the kinematics of the gas as it flows into/out of these objects. We hence estimate the time based upon 10 km/s channels, which will allow an accurate derivation of the gas kinematics. We retain the flexibility to rebin in post-processing to obtain greater signal to noise on weak lines, or higher velocity resolution on bright regions.
The continuum brightness estimate is based on extrapolating black-body fits based upon our Herschel data. Detecting the continuum does not drive our science case, but we will achieve S/N>5 in many cases.

We aim here to detect the CO(1-0) line in these systems and, as argued above, we require ~10 km/s channels. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz (about 2.5 km/s), which we will bin up to 10 km/s in post processing. This configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning for face on sources, or increase it for edge-on systems to get higher sensitivity. We place one spectral window on 12CO, one on shock tracer CH3OH, one on outflow tracer HC3N, and another on the CN lines (but these do not drive our time estimate). We will use 4x spectral averaging for these windows in order to reduce the data rate, as these lines, if present, are expected to be weak. These windows can also be used to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).

As above, we have assumed that the flux will be only marginally resolved each channel (tracing the spider diagram of the velocity field), as the dust (which is almost always spatially coincident with the molecular gas; Alatalo et al. 2013) visible in the optical image of this object (see Figure 1) appears relatively edge-on. We hence estimate the LAS should be ~2" in each channel, and as such we do not expect to resolve out flux. Even if the molecular gas morphology is extremely different to that of the dust, we still expect not to lose flux as the LAS accessible in this array configuration (25.2") extends well beyond the effective radii of these objects.
We will compare this very suppressed early-type galaxy with existing observations of normal gas-rich galaxies (Davis et al. 2014, Leroy et al. 2009), which have been mapped at ~1 kpc resolution. Our angular resolution is chosen so that we have approximately the same physical resolution (which corresponds to 1.5" at the distance of this object), allowing easy comparison and ensuring we will obtain more than 5 beams across the minor merger remnant. This is also the scale where one expects to see large-scale streaming and inflow of gas.

The selected galaxy has a mean line flux of 9.2 mJy/chan, with a line width of 450 km/s based on our IRAM observations (see Figure 1). We assume that this flux will be spread over at most two beam widths in each channel, as the dust (which is almost always spatially coincident with the molecular gas; Alatalo et al. 2013) visible in the optical image of this object (see Figure 1) relativly edge-on. Thus the flux per beam we need to detect is 4.6 mJy/beam. Requiring a 5 sigma detection of this flux (in order to ensure an accurate estimate of the gas kinematics) yields our requested RMS of 0.92 mJy/beam.
As discussed in our science case, the aim of this proposal is to map the kinematics of the gas as it flows into/out of these objects. We hence estimate the time based upon 10 km/s channels, which will allow an accurate derivation of the gas kinematics. We retain the flexibility to rebin in post-processing to obtain greater signal to noise on weak lines, or higher velocity resolution on bright regions.
The continuum brightness estimate is based on extrapolating black-body fits based upon our Herschel data. Detecting the continuum does not drive our science case, but we will achieve S/N>5 in many cases.

We aim here to detect the CO(1-0) line in these systems and, as argued above, we require ~10 km/s channels. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz (about 2.5 km/s), which we will bin up to 10 km/s in post processing. This configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning for face on sources, or increase it for edge-on systems to get higher sensitivity. We place one spectral window on 12CO, one on shock tracer CH3OH, one on outflow tracer HC3N, and another on the CN lines (but these do not drive our time estimate). We will use 4x spectral averaging for these windows in order to reduce the data rate, as these lines, if present, are expected to be weak. These windows can also be used to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).

Even if the molecular gas morphology is extremely different to that of the dust, we still expect not to lose flux as the LAS accessible in this array configuration (25.2") extends well beyond the effective radii of these objects.
We will compare this very suppressed early-type galaxy with existing observations of normal gas-rich galaxies (Davis et al. 2014, Leroy et al. 2009), which have been mapped at ~1 kpc resolution. Our angular resolution is chosen so that we have approximately the same physical resolution (which corresponds to 1.5" at the distance of this object), allowing easy comparison and ensuring we will obtain more than 5 beams across the minor merger remnant. This is also the scale where one expects to see large-scale streaming and inflow of gas.

The selected galaxy has a mean line flux of 9.4 mJy/chan, with a line width of 445 km/s based on our IRAM observations (see Figure 1). We assume that this flux will be spread over at most two beam widths in each channel, as the dust (which is almost always spatially coincident with the molecular gas; Alatalo et al. 2013) visible in the optical image of this object (see Figure 1) appears nearly edge-on. Thus the flux per beam we need to detect is 4.7 mJy/beam. Requiring a 5 sigma detection of this flux (in order to ensure an accurate estimate of the gas kinematics) yields our requested RMS of 0.94 mJy/beam.
As discussed in our science case, the aim of this proposal is to map the kinematics of the gas as it flows into/out of these objects. We hence estimate the time based upon 10 km/s channels, which will allow an accurate derivation of the gas kinematics. We retain the flexibility to rebin in post-processing to obtain greater signal to noise on weak lines, or higher velocity resolution on bright regions.
The continuum brightness estimate is based on extrapolating black-body fits based upon our Herschel data. Detecting the continuum does not drive our science case, but we will achieve S/N>5 in many cases.

We aim here to detect the CO(1-0) line in these systems and, as argued above, we require ~10 km/s channels. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz (about 2.5 km/s), which we will bin up to 10 km/s in post processing. This configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning for face on sources, or increase it for edge-on systems to get higher sensitivity. We place one spectral window on 12CO, one on shock tracer CH3OH, one on outflow tracer HC3N, and another on the CN lines (but these do not drive our time estimate). We will use 4x spectral averaging for these windows in order to reduce the data rate, as these lines, if present, are expected to be weak. These windows can also be used to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).

As above, we have assumed that the flux will be only marginally resolved each channel (tracing the spider diagram of the velocity field), as the dust (which is almost always spatially coincident with the molecular gas; Alatalo et al. 2013) visible in the optical image of this object (see Figure 1) appears relatively edge-on. We hence estimate the LAS should be ~6" in each channel, and as such we do not expect to resolve out flux. Even if the molecular gas morphology is extremely different to that of the dust, we still expect not to lose flux as the LAS accessible in this array configuration (25.2") extends well beyond the effective radii of these objects.
We will compare this very suppressed early-type galaxy with existing observations of normal gas-rich galaxies (Davis et al. 2014, Leroy et al. 2009), which have been mapped at ~1 kpc resolution. Our angular resolution is chosen so that we have approximately the same physical resolution (which corresponds to 1.5" at the distance of this object), allowing easy comparison and ensuring we will obtain more than 5 beams across the minor merger remnant. This is also the scale where one expects to see large-scale streaming and inflow of gas.

The selected galaxy has a mean line flux of 27.6 mJy/chan, with a line width of 455 km/s based on our IRAM observations (see Figure 1). We assume that this flux will be spread over at most four beam widths in each channel, as the minor axis of the dust (which is almost always spatially coincident with the molecular gas; Alatalo et al. 2013) visible in the optical image of this object (see Figure 1) appears to extend to around 6". Thus the flux per beam we need to detect is 6.9 mJy/beam. Requiring a 5 sigma detection of this flux (in order to ensure an accurate estimate of the gas kinematics) yields our requested RMS of 1.38 mJy/beam.
As discussed in our science case, the aim of this proposal is to map the kinematics of the gas as it flows into/out of these objects. We hence estimate the time based upon 10 km/s channels, which will allow an accurate derivation of the gas kinematics. We retain the flexibility to rebin in post-processing to obtain greater signal to noise on weak lines, or higher velocity resolution on bright regions.
The continuum brightness estimate is based on extrapolating black-body fits based upon our Herschel data. Detecting the continuum does not drive our science case, but we will achieve S/N>5 in many cases.

We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz (about 2.5 km/s), which we will bin up to 10 km/s in post processing. We will use 4x spectral averaging for these windows in order to reduce the data rate, as these lines, if present, are expected to be weak. Our angular resolution is chosen so that we have approximately the same physical resolution (which corresponds to 1.5" at the distance of this object), allowing easy comparison and ensuring we will obtain more than 5 beams across the minor merger remnant. this is also the scale where one expects to see large-scale streaming and inflow of gas.

The selected galaxy has a mean line flux of 16 mJy/chan, with a line width of 410 km/s based on our IRAM observations (see Figure 1). We assume that this flux will be spread over at most two beam widths in each channel, as the dust (which is almost always spatially coincident with the molecular gas; Alatalo et al. 2013) visible in the optical image of this object (see Figure 1) appears nearly edge-on. Thus the flux per beam we need to detect is 8 mJy/beam. Requiring a 5 sigma detection of this flux (in order to ensure an accurate estimate of the gas kinematics) yields our requested RMS of 1.61 mJy/beam.
As discussed in our science case, the aim of this proposal is to map the kinematics of the gas as it flows into/out of these objects. We hence estimate the time based upon 10 km/s channels, which will allow an accurate derivation of the gas kinematics. We retain the flexibility to rebin in post-processing to obtain greater signal to noise on weak lines, or higher velocity resolution on bright regions.
The continuum brightness estimate is based on extrapolating black-body fits based upon our Herschel data. Detecting the continuum does not drive our science case, but we will achieve S/N>5 in many cases.

We aim here to detect the CO(1-0) line in these systems and, as argued above, we require ~10 km/s channels. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz (about 2.5 km/s), which we will bin up to 10 km/s in post processing. This configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning for face on sources, or increase it for edge-on systems to get higher sensitivity. We place one spectral window on 12CO, one on shock tracer CH3OH, one on outflow tracer HC3N, and another on the CN lines (but these do not drive our time estimate). We will use 4x spectral averaging for these windows in order to reduce the data rate, as these lines, if present, are expected to be weak. Even if the molecular gas morphology is extremely different to that of the dust, we still expect not to lose flux as the LAS accessible in this array configuration (25.2") extends well beyond the effective radii of these objects.
We will compare this very suppressed early-type galaxy with existing observations of normal gas-rich galaxies (Davis et al. 2014, Leroy et al. 2009), which have been mapped at ~1 kpc resolution. Our angular resolution is chosen so that we have approximately the same physical resolution (which corresponds to 1.5" at the distance of this object), allowing easy comparison and ensuring we will obtain more than 5 beams across the minor merger remnant. This is also the scale where one expects to see large-scale streaming and inflow of gas.

The selected galaxy has a mean line flux of 13.8 mJy/chan, with a line width of 460 km/s based on our IRAM observations (see Figure 1). We assume that this flux will be spread over at most two beam widths in each channel, as the dust (which is almost always spatially coincident with the molecular gas; Alatalo et al. 2013) visible in the optical image of this object (see Figure 1) appears nearly edge-on. Thus the flux per beam we need to detect is 6.9 mJy/beam. As discussed in our science case, the aim of this proposal is to map the kinematics of the gas as it flows into/out of these objects. We hence estimate the time based upon 10 km/s channels, which will allow an accurate derivation of the gas kinematics. We retain the flexibility to rebin in post-processing to obtain greater signal-to-noise on weak lines, or higher velocity resolution on bright regions.
The continuum brightness estimate is based on extrapolating black-body fits based upon our Herschel data. Detecting the continuum does not drive our science case, but we will achieve S/N>5 in many cases.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In a hierarchical LambdaCDM universe mergers play a major role in the assembly of galaxies, inducing strong star formation, fuelling black-hole growth and morphologically transforming galaxies. Wet mergers are usually associated with strong starbursts, as gas dissipatively collapses to the galaxy centre. A recent paper by Davis et al. (2015) found a population of very gas rich galaxies, which have recently undergone a minor merger. Contrary to expectations these coalesced systems do not host strong starbursts. Instead star formation is suppressed by orders of magnitude, with gas depletion times that exceed the Hubble time. We propose to use ALMA to determine the underlying physical cause of this intriguing effect, distinguishing between dynamical suppression, gravitational heating and AGN/starburst feedback both kinematically and chemically. A small investment of ALMA time will allow us to place these objects on a 'suppression sequence', comparing them to more normal early-type and star-forming objects, and to purpose-built hydrodynamic simulations. In this way we can shed light on a physical process that can suppress and regulate star formation across the Universe.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
